title: 110_hr2455
content: The "Social Security Number Non-Proliferation Act of 2007" prohibits the sale, purchase, and public display of Social Security account numbers. This amendment follows Title II of the Social Security Act. The "Social Security Number Non-Proliferation Act of 2007" defines the term 'person' as any individual, partnership, corporation, trust, estate, cooperative, association, or any other entity, excluding governmental entities. It also prohibits the sale of Social Security account numbers. The "Social Security Number Non-Proliferation Act of 2007" prohibits the sale or purchase of Social Security account numbers, except when submitting the number as part of applying for government benefits or programs. The term 'display to the general public' refers to intentionally making a social security account number visible on a public internet site or in any other way that allows access by the general public. When a person requires the transmittal of an individual's social security account number without proper encryption, it is considered a public display of the number. The term 'social security account number' includes any derivative of the number, but expressions on items sold to the general public are not considered social security numbers. The public display of a social security account number, including the last 4 digits, is not considered a violation as long as the full number cannot be determined. It is illegal to sell, purchase, or display a social security account number to the general public, or use it to harm an individual or for illegal purposes. The social security account number can be sold or purchased for specific purposes such as law enforcement, national security, public health, and emergency situations to protect individuals' health or safety. The sale or purchase of social security account numbers is allowed for specific purposes such as tax law compliance, consumer reporting agencies, and research for the public good. The researcher must ensure that social security account numbers are not used in a way that could harm individuals or affect their rights, benefits, or privileges. They must also have safeguards in place to protect the privacy and confidentiality of any information obtained, including encrypting or securing the numbers from unauthorized disclosure. Individuals' social security account numbers must be appropriately secured from unauthorized disclosure. However, with the individual's voluntary written consent, the number may be sold, purchased, or displayed to the public under certain conditions. The Commissioner of Social Security must consult with the Office for Civil Rights of the Department of Health and Human Services to ensure that the sale or purchase of social security account numbers for medical research complies with existing Federal rules and regulations. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 prohibits unauthorized disclosure of social security account numbers to government agencies without written permission, except when requested by the agency. Legal representatives can provide permission for legally incompetent individuals. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 prohibits the display of social security account numbers on cards or tags for access to goods, services, or benefits. This prohibition also applies to employee identification cards. Law enforcement and national security purposes are exceptions to this rule. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 prohibits displaying social security numbers on employee identification cards, except for certain authorized purposes. Additionally, measures must be taken to prevent unauthorized access to social security numbers in business records. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 prohibits displaying social security numbers on employee identification cards and requires safeguards to prevent unauthorized access to these numbers in business records. The act also specifies restrictions on the use of social security numbers for trade or business purposes and imposes criminal penalties for violations. Any violation of the section mentioned in the previous text will result in a felony charge with a maximum penalty of 5 years imprisonment or a fine under title 18, United States Code. This section does not override any existing restrictions on the sale, purchase, or disclosure of social security numbers if those restrictions are stricter than those outlined here. Regulations will be issued to enforce the provisions of this section. The Commissioner of Social Security must consult with various government agencies and entities, including the Attorney General, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and State insurance commissioners, to issue regulations regarding specific subsections. Other U.S. agencies can also issue regulations under the Commissioner's authority if deemed appropriate. The Commissioner of Social Security may authorize the sale or purchase of social security account numbers if it serves a compelling public interest and does not pose a risk of harm to individuals. The Commissioner of Social Security may authorize the sale, purchase, or display of social security account numbers to the general public after considering factors like cost and benefit. Restrictions will be imposed if authorization is granted. The Commissioner may impose restrictions on the sale, purchase, or display of social security account numbers to prevent fraud, identity theft, or harm to individuals. Notice must be provided when issuing regulations. The Commissioner may impose restrictions on social security account numbers to prevent fraud. Notice and opportunity for participation in rule making must be provided as per regulations. Agencies must consult and coordinate to ensure consistency in regulations. Initial final regulations under section 208A of the Social Security Act must be issued by the 18th date. The final regulations under section 208A of the Social Security Act must be issued within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. These regulations will take effect 1 year after issuance and apply to displays to the general public occurring after this 1-year period, excluding displays of records containing social security account numbers generated before that time.
